In this article, we discuss the most general case, which is convex analysis on vector Spaces.

For a vector space $U$, we do not specify the topology structure, so we do not know the specific concepts of open and closed sets, and naturally it is difficult to distinguish the inner and boundary of convex sets. However, it is possible to define a kind of "in-algebra" concept: for the convex set $C$on the vector space $U$, the set
\bigg\{x \in C \bigg| \forall v \in U, \exists \gamma_v > 0 , \forall \gamma \in [0,\gamma_v], x + \gamma v \in C\bigg\}

of $C$, we denote it as $\mathop{ \mathrm{ core} } C$. In other words, inside the algebra of a set are points that can take a small step in any direction and still be within $C$. This concept is very natural, and fits with the concept of interior in Euclidean space.
